questions.question: Match the images of IOL malpositions with their names: Image Syndrome a. 1. Sunrise syndrome b. 2. Lost lens syndrome c. 3. Sunset syndrome
Toric IOLs are specifically designed to correct which type of refractive error?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Astigmatism Explanation: Astigmatism: Common refractive error where refraction changes in different meridians of the eye.Toric IOLs have an integral cylindrical refractive component to compensate for pre-existing corneal astigmatism and improve vision clarity for patients with astigmatism. Types of Intraocular Lenses (IOLs): Based on method of fixation in the eye: Anterior chamber IOL Iris supported lens Lenses which lie completely in front of iris and are supported in the angle of anterior chamber. (S shaped haptic) Presently, AC-IOL are used in those cases where it is not possible to use PC-IOL (made of PMMA) Eg - Kelman multiflex Lenses are fixed on the Iris, with the help of suture,claws or loops. They have high incidents of post-operative complications. Eg - Singh and Worst’s Iris claw lens Posterior chamber IOL Scleral fixated IOL (SFIOL) PC-IOL can rest in ciliary sulcus. Capsular bag fixation of PCIOL is the most ideal method. Eg - C loop type and four loop type. They are preferred in cases of ectopia lentis and inadequate capsular support. The optic of the IOL is placed in the posterior chamber. The haptic is fixed to the sclera approximately 1.5 to 2 mm from the limbus. SFIOL can be performed either with sutures or in a sutureless manner (Yamane technique). Special function IOL Toric IOL: Designed to correct astigmatism (Option C) Aspheric IOL: Designed to reduce spherical aberrations Aniridia IOL: Designed to cover defects of aniridia or partial iris loss. Based on the focussing ability the IOLs are of following types: Unifocal IOLs are the most commonly used ones having unifocal power. Depending upon the power of IOLs implanted, these can make the patient emmetropic, myopic or hypermetropic Multifocal lOLs have separate optics to focus for distance and near, so also known as simultaneous vision lenses. These are of 2 types, either refractive or diffractive optics types. These are also called pseudo accommodative IOLs. Accommodative IOLs exhibit some anterior movement of optic to improve the near vision. Available models of accommodative IOLs are: Crystalens and Synchrony lens Extended-depth-of-Focus IOL- e.g. Technis Symphony, provides uncorrected distance, intermediate as well as near vision to some extent due to its elongated focus. Myopia (Option A ): Not specifically corrected by Toric IOLs. Standard monofocal IOLs are typically used for correcting myopia. Hypermetropia (Option B) : Can be corrected with standard IOLs, but Toric IOLs are not designed specifically for this condition. Presbyopia (Option D) : Age-related condition where the eye loses its ability to focus on near objects. Multifocal or EDOF IOLs are typically used to address presbyopia, not Toric IOLs.

questions.question: Which of the following is considered the best formula for intraocular lens (IOL) power calculation after LASIK surgery?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Haigis Explanation: Haigis formula is particularly well-regarded for post-LASIK eyes. It uses two variables: axial length & anterior chamber depth, making it more adaptable to eyes that have undergone refractive surgery. This adaptability generally provides more accurate IOL power calculations in post-LASIK cases. Biometry: Method of calculating IOL power by 2 methods - Keratometry and Axial length Equipments used: A scan ultrasound for axial length Formulas used: SRK (Option A) Hoffer Q (Option B) Holladay I (Option D) P= A-2.5L-0.9K (L= axial length) (K= constant) Normal axial length (24 mm) Short axial length (<22mm) Long axial length ( >24.5 mm) Reference: AK Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 7th edition, page 216 Kanski’s clinical ophthalmology, 9th edition, Page 316 Biometry

questions.question: In which scenario is a posterior capsule tear more commonly observed during cataract surgery?

options.A: During phacoemulsification with high energy settings
options.B: During cortical clean-up with a manual irrigation-aspiration technique
options.D: During anterior chamber maintenance with a viscoelastic substance

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) During cortical clean-up with a manual irrigation-aspiration technique is due to the mechanical stress and manipulation involved in removing residual cortex, which can sometimes lead to inadvertent damage to the posterior capsule. More common in SICS and Phacoemulsification procedures. Can occur in following situations - During forceful hydrodissection. - Direct injury with Sinskey’s hook, chopper. - During cortex aspiration. - Manual irrigation-aspiration technique. Operative complications of Cataract surgery: Superior rectus muscle laceration Button holding of anterior wall of tunnel Scleral disinsertion Descemet’s detachment Iridodialysis Zonular dehiscence Vitreous prolapse and loss Nucleus drop into vitreous cavity Posterior loss of lens fragments Expulsive choroidal haemorrhage During phacoemulsification with high energy settings (Option A) : They are more likely to cause issues like corneal edema or endothelial damage rather than directly causing a posterior capsule tear. During hydrodelineation (Option C) : This technique generally helps separate the lens from the capsule and is less likely to cause a tear if performed correctly. During anterior chamber maintenance with a viscoelastic substance (Option D) : Maintaining the anterior chamber with viscoelastic substances is designed to protect intraocular structures and reduce complications. Reference: AK Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 7th edition, page 218 & 219. Kanski’s clinical ophthalmology, 9th edition, Page 316

questions.question: A 70-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and high myopia undergoes cataract surgery. During the procedure, she suddenly experiences severe ocular pain and a rapid rise in intraocular pressure. Fundoscopic examination reveals a dark red elevation in the choroidal region. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate management step?

options.B: Increase the infusion pressure in the anterior chamber
options.C: Perform immediate vitrectomy to drain the hemorrhage
options.D: Close the surgical wound and monitor intraocular pressure

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Close the surgical wound and monitor intraocular pressure Explanation: The given clinical scenario suggests suprachoroidal hemorrhage . The immediate steps involve closing the wound to prevent further prolapse of intraocular contents and monitoring intraocular pressure. Suprachoroidal hemorrhage: A suprachoroidal haemorrhage involves a bleed into the suprachoroidal space from a ruptured short posterior ciliary artery. If suciently severe, it may result in extrusion of intraocular contents (expulsive haemorrhage). It is a dreaded complication, but extremely rare (0.04%) with phacoemulsication. Signs: Progressive shallowing of the AC, increased IOP, and iris prolapse. Vitreous extrusion, loss or partial obscuration of the red reflex and the appearance of a dark mound behind the pupil. In severe cases, posterior segment contents may be extruded into the AC and through the incision. Management: Immediate Subsequate Closure of the incision with a suture to retain residual viscoelastic in the eye. Diagnosis should be confirmed at the slit-lamp as soon as possible. Acetazolamide to lower intraocular pressure. Intensive topical and systemic steroids to reduce inflammation, with standard postoperative antibiotic treatment and IOP management. Drainage, if subsequent hemorrhage fails to resolve (after 7-14 days, by which liquefaction of blood clot has taken place). Pars plana vitrectomy may be considered when the retina appears adherent or detached. Intraoperative posterior sclerostomy (Option A) should not be performed during the management of suprachoroidal hemorrhage because it increases the risk of complications such as infection and retinal detachment. The immediate focus should be on stabilizing the eye by controlling intraocular pressure and closing the incision. Once stabilized, further surgical interventions can be evaluated in a safer environment. Increase the infusion pressure in the anterior chamber (Option B): Increasing infusion pressure may worsen the bleeding. Perform immediate vitrectomy to drain the hemorrhage (Option C): Immediate vitrectomy is generally avoided initially as it could exacerbate the hemorrhage.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a condition associated with a shallow anterior chamber?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Iridodialysis Explanation: Iridodialysis, which is a separation of the iris from its attachment to the ciliary body, typically does not cause a shallow anterior chamber. Flat/Shallow anterior chamber Early Postoperative complications of cataract surgery. It may occur due to wound leak, ciliochoroidal detachment and pupil block. Flat anterior chamber with wound leak: (Option A) Associated with hypotony, diagnosed by Seidel's test.Fluorescein diluted by aqueous at site of leakage. Treatment: Most cases cured within 4 days with pressure bandage and oral acetazolamide.If persistent: injection of air in anterior chamber and suturing of leaking wound. Ciliochoroidal detachment: (Option B) Presents as convex brownish mass in an involved quadrant with shallow anterior chamber. Treatment: Most cases cured within 4 days with pressure bandage and oral acetazolamide.If persistent, suprachoroidal drainage with injection of air in anterior chamber. Pupil block due to vitreous bulge: (Option C) Occurs after ICCE and in ECCE technique due to adhesions with IOL (more common with ACIOLs). Leads to formation of iris bombe and shallowing of anterior chamber. If persistent for 5-7 days, it may form permanent peripheral anterior synechiae (PAS) leading to secondary angle closure glaucoma. Treatment: Initially treated with mydriatic, hyperosmotic agents (e.g. 20% mannitol) and acetazolamide.If not relieved, laser peripheral iridotomy should be performed to bypass the pupillary block IIIIIIIII . Reference: AK Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 7th edition, page 219,220&221. Kanski’s clinical ophthalmology, 9th edition, Page 900

questions.question: A 67-year-old man had undergone cataract surgery. He presents with endophthalmitis after 3 days. His infection is severe with vision reduced to hand movements close to the face. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Vitrectomy Explanation: The given scenario is of post-operative acute bacterial endophthalmitis. A vitrectomy is done if no improvement in 48-72 hours or if severe infection with vision reduced to hand movements close to the face Acute endophthalmitis : Definition Inflammation of inner structures of the eye (uveal tissue and retina) with exudates in the vitreous, anterior, and posterior chambers. It spares sclera. Acute bacterial endophthalmitis happens 1-7 days post intraocular surgery M/C causative organism Staphylococcus epidermidis Presentation Severe ocular pain Redness Lacrimation Photophobia Loss of vision Red and swollen lids Conjunctival chemosis Circumcorneal congestion Cloudy cornea Ring infiltration Yellow necrotic wound edges Hypopyon Oedematous and muddy iris Yellow pupil reflex due to purulent exudation Vitreous exudation which causes amaurotic cat's-eye reflex Raised intraocular pressure initially Treatment Intravitreal antibiotics: First choice: Vancomycin 1 mg + Ceftazidime 2.25 mg Second choice: Vancomycin 1 mg + Amikacin 0.4 mg Topical antibiotics Systemic antibiotics Steroid Therapy Supportive Therapy Vitrectomy - if no improvement in 48-72 hours or if severe infection with vision reduced to hand movements close to the face If blind - no perception of light - Evisceration.

questions.question: A 65-year-old man has undergone cataract surgery. He has now returned after 6 weeks with endophthalmitis. What is the most likely organism that caused the infection?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Propionibacterium acnes Explanation: The scenario is that of late-onset postoperative endophthalmitis Endophthalmitis is inflammation of the inner structures of the eye (uveal tissue and retina) with exudates in the vitreous, anterior, and posterior chambers Delayed onset endophthalmitis: Onset After 6-weeks of intraocular surgery Course Slow, with a panuveitis-like picture Clinical Features Granulomatous keratic precipitates Inflammatory deposits over intraocular lens (IOL) White capsular plaque Anterior chamber reaction Vitritis Cystoid macular edema (CME) Response to Treatment May respond to periocular or systemic steroids but usually recurs Common Causative Organisms Bacterial: Propionibacterium acnes (most common) , Coagulase-negative Staphylococcus Fungal: Aspergillus, Candida, and others Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK559079/ Kanski’s clinical ophthalmology, 9th edition, Page 330

questions.question: Soemmering's Ring and Elschnig's Pearls are examples of which of the following?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) After cataracts Explanation: After cataract = Secondary cataract: Definition M/C postoperative complication following extracapsular lens extraction. Clinical Types Posterior Capsule Opacification (PCO) : Common form of after cataract. Dense Membranous After Cataract: Thick membrane formation. Soemmering's Ring: Thick ring behind the iris, enclosed between capsule layers. Elschnig's Pearls: Clustered, vacuolated subcapsular epithelial cells along the posterior capsule. Treatment ND YAG laser posterior capsulotomy

questions.question: A key advantage of peribulbar anesthesia over retrobulbar anesthesia is:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Less risk of globe perforation Explanation: Peribulbar anesthesia is associated with a lower risk of globe perforation because the anesthetic is injected outside the muscle cone, reducing the likelihood of accidentally penetrating the eye. Features Retrobulbar block Peribulbar block Injection Site Inside the muscle cone (intraconal) Outside the muscle cone (extraconal) Onset of Anesthesia Faster onset (Option A) Slower onset Akinesia (Eye Movement) Better akinesia due to direct nerve blockade (Option C) Variable akinesia,may require multiple injections Risk of Globe Perforation and Optic nerve injury Higher risk due to proximity to the globe and optic nerve Lower risk Hemorrhage Risk Higher risk of retrobulbar hemorrhage Lower risk of severe hemorrhage Reduced risk of systemic toxicity (Option D) is generally low in both techniques, but peribulbar anesthesia does not significantly reduce this risk compared to retrobulbar anesthesia.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding Cystoid Macular Edema?

options.A: Collection of fluid in Henle’s layer
options.C: Antiprostaglandin is both treatment and prevention

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All of the above Explanation: Cystoid macular edema: Definition Collection of fluid in cystic loculi in the Henle's layer of the macula Defect in OPL layer of retina( inner retinal blood barrier break defect) Frequent complication of cataract surgery Fundoscopy Honeycomb appearance Fluorescein Angiography Flower petal pattern Prevention Preoperative and postoperative use of anti prostaglandin eye drops (indomethacin, flurbiprofen, or ketorolac) Treatment Anterior vitrectomy Steroids Antiprostaglandins Reference: Kanski’s clinical ophthalmology, 9th edition, Page 602

questions.question: What is the common inheritance pattern of hereditary cataracts?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Autosomal dominant Explanation: Cataracts can be inherited without systemic disorders in the autosomal dominant pattern Etiology of congenital cataract: Idiopathic Sporadic cases with unknown etiology. Hereditary Inherited without Systemic Disorders: Usually autosomal dominant. Genes: Cry-G (crystallins). Connexins. MIP (Major intrinsic protein). Inherited with Systemic Disorders: Chromosomal disorders (e.g., trisomy 21) Skeletal disorders (e.g., Stickler syndrome) CNS disorders (e.g., cerebro-oculo-facial syndrome) Renal system disorders (e.g., Lowe's syndrome) Maternal Factors 1. Malnutrition during Pregnancy: Associated with nonfamilial zonular cataract. 2. Infections: Rubella (50% of cases), toxoplasmosis, cytomegalic inclusion disease. 3. Drug Ingestion: Certain drugs (e.g., thalidomide, corticosteroids) during pregnancy. 4. Radiation Exposure: Maternal exposure to radiation during pregnancy. Foetal or Infantile Factors 1. Deficient Oxygenation (Anoxia): Due to placental hemorrhage. 2. Birth Trauma 3. Metabolic Disorders: Galactosemia, galactokinase deficiency, neonatal hypoglycemia. 4. Associated with Congenital Anomalies: Down's syndrome, Lowe's syndrome, myotonia dystrophica, congenital ichthyosis. 5. Ocular Diseases: Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV), aniridia, anterior chamber cleavage syndrome, retinopathy of prematurity, lenticonus posterior, microphthalmos. 6. Malnutrition in Early Infancy

questions.question: Doctor noticed leukocoria in a 3-month-old baby during a routine examination and the eye appeared as shown below. Choose the least appropriate statement regarding the most likely diagnosis.

options.A: Most common type of congenital cataract
options.B: Commonly inherited as autosomal dominant trait
options.C: Usually zone of fetal nucleus is involved

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Most common type of congenital cataract Explanation: The image is of lamellar cataract Types of Congenital cataract: Polar cataracts Anterior polar cataract: Usually associated with persistent pupillary membrane. Non-axial, stationary, asymptomatic. Posterior polar cataract: Onion ring / whorled appearance Associated with : mittendorf dots PHPV PITX 3 Mutation Congenital nuclear cataracts Cataracta centralis pulverulenta: Powdery opacity at the center of lens. Usually does not cause vision problems. Lamellar cataract: (zonular cataract) Most common congenital cataract affecting vision Infantile cataract <1 yr child Associated with genetic and environmental causes like vitamin-D deficiency (Option D) , congenital rubella syndrome ( but m/c in this is pearly white cataract) Inherited as an autosomal dominant trait. (Option B) Zone of the fetal nucleus is involved. (Option C) Radial opacities (Riders) are seen. Sutural cataract: Punctate opacities scattered around Y-sutures Patterns: Floriform, Coralliform, Dendritic sutural Generalized cataracts Coronary cataract: Adolescent onset cataract Numerous club-shaped opacities in the periphery Blue dot cataract

questions.question: An infant with leukocoria presents with recurrent gastrointestinal infections and developmental regression. Bilateral eye examination revealed the following. Choose the most appropriate next step in evaluation.

options.A: Serum estimation of glucose, calcium, and phosphorous levels
options.B: Estimation of antibody titers for infections
options.D: Urine assay for the presence of reducing substances

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Urine assay for the presence of reducing substances Explanation: Given clinical scenario is indicative of Classical galactosemia. Description Inborn error of galactose metabolism. Description and types Classical Galactosaemia: deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GPUT). Non-classical type: Galactokinase deficiency Characteristic Features Frequently leads to bilateral cataract formation. Cataracts often present as oil droplet central lens opacities. Recurrent infections with Escherichia coli. Mental retardation/developmental delay. Management and prognosis Avoidance of milk and milk-based products. Cataract changes are reversible. Biochemical analysis: Blood analysis Levels of blood glucose, calcium and phosphorus to rule out Hyperglycemia and Hypocalcemia. (Option A) Red blood cell transferase and galactokinase levels - for Galactosemia. Antibody titres for infections such as toxoplasmosis, rubella, cytomegalovirus and herpes simplex virus (TORCH) and hepatitis B virus. (Option B) Urine analysis Urine assay for reducing substances - for Galactosaemia. (Option D) Screening for amino acids in the urine - if Lowe syndrome is

questions.question: A 1-month-old infant is diagnosed with a dense unilateral cataract. Which of the following is the most appropriate management strategy?

options.A: Delay surgery until the child is 1–2 years old to reduce surgical risks
options.C: Prescribe glasses and monitor the cataract progression
options.D: Wait until the child develops strabismus before considering surgery

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Perform immediate cataract surgery Explanation: Management of congenital cataract: Timing of Surgery Unilateral cataracts: as early as possible. (Option B) After 1 month of age for bilateral cataracts. (Option A) Surgical Technique Small, ideally 1–1.5 mm limbal incisions. Posterior capsulorhexis with pars plana vitrectomy is done additionally to reduce the risk of After-cataract. Optical Rehabilitation Contact lenses/glasses: for children below 2 years age IOLs: Generally preferred in children above 2 years age Foldable hydrophobic acrylic IOLs are preferred over PMMA. Always placed with undercorrection. Prescribe glasses and monitor the cataract progression (Option C) : Glasses are used post cataract surgery and are not the mainstay of treatment. Wait until the child develops strabismus before considering surgery (Option D) : Waiting until complications is not advised in dense unilateral cataracts as it can lead to permanent vision impairment. Reference: Parson’s diseases of the Eye - 23rd edition, page-641,642 Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana - 7th edition, page 192

questions.question: A newborn presented with the following findings. There is a positive maternal history for fever during the first trimester of pregnancy. Which among the following is least likely to be seen in this newborn?

A school-going child is diagnosed with a connective tissue disorder characterized by abnormalities of the eye, short stature, brachydactyly, joint stiffness, and cardiovascular defects. Which among the following is incorrect regarding the likely diagnosis?

options.A: Follows autosomal recessive mode of inheritance
options.D: Usual age of presentation is 5-10 years

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Associated with supero-temporal lens dislocation Explanation : The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Weill-Marchesani syndrome , in which there is inferior subluxation of the lens, not supero-temporal displacement Ectopia Lentis - Systemic associations: Marfan's Syndrome Autosomal dominant B/L Supero-temporal dislocation , Megalocornea Arachnodactyly, long limbs, hypermobile joints , cardiovascular defects Homocystinuria Autosomal recessive Infero-nasal dislocation A/w zonular breaks and hence loss of accommodation Detection of homocysteine in urine using the sodium nitroprusside test. Weill-Marchesani Syndrome Autosomal recessive (Option A) Microspherophakia, Inferior or forward subluxation of the lens Short stature, brachydactyly, joint stiffness , cardiovascular defects. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome Lens subluxation, blue sclera , Hyperextensible joints Stickler Syndrome Liquified vitreous, retinal detachment, Pre-senile cataract Oro-facial abnormalities, arthropathy Sulphite Oxidase Deficiency Autosomal recessive Ectopia lentis, Progressive muscular rigidity Death usually by 5 years of age Molecular genetic analysis is confirmatory (Option C) : Genetic testing for ADAMTS10/ADAMTS17 (Autosomal Recessive) or FBN1 (Autosomal dominant) variants is diagnostic of Weill-Marchesani syndrome. The usual age of presentation is 5-10 years (Option D) : The mean age of presentation is 7.5 years, the majority of cases present in the first decade of life.

questions.question: Which of the following is the thinnest part of the lens capsule?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Posterior pole Explanation: The Capsule at the posterior pole (4 microns) is the thinnest part. Lens capsule: Thickest basement membrane in the body. Posterior pole: Thinnest part (Capsule), measuring around 4 micrometers, due to fewer cells and less collagen. Lens Nucleus: The central part contains the oldest fibers in different zones, which are laid down successively as the development proceeds. Embryonic nucleus: Innermost part of nucleus corresponding to the lens up to the first 3 months of gestation. Consists of primary lens fibers. Fetal nucleus: Surrounding embryonic nucleus which corresponds to the lens from 3 months of gestation till birth. Fibers are anteriorly Y-shaped and posteriorly inverted Y-shaped. Infantile nucleus: Corresponds to the lens from birth to puberty and surrounds the fetal nucleus. Adult nucleus: Corresponds to lens fibers formed after puberty to rest of life. Anterior pole (Option A): Thicker part of the lens capsule, providing support and maintaining curvature. Equator (Option C): Moderately thick, where zonular fibers attach for lens accommodation. Pre-equatorial region (Option D): The thickest portion of the lens capsule measuring 12-14 micrometers supports zonular attachments.

questions.question: What are the steps involved in FLACS? → Corneal Incision → Lens Fragmentation → IOL implantation → Capsulorrhexis → Lens Fragmentation → IOL implantation → Lens Fragmentation → Corneal Incision → IOL implantation → Lens Fragmentation → Capsulorrhexis → IOL implantation
questions.explanation: → Lens Fragmentation → Corneal Incision → IOL implantation Correct Answer : C) Capsulorrhexis → Lens Fragmentation → Corneal Incision → IOL implantation treatment, classified as a microincision cataract surgery (MICS) technique due to its use of a very small incision, typically less than 2 mm . FLACS employs a femtosecond laser (FSL) to perform specific surgical steps with enhanced precision and safety. This precision can reduce the amount of ultrasound energy needed during phacoemulsification , which is advantageous for patients with preexisting retinal conditions, such as diabetic retinopathy . FLACS is suitable for patients with pre-existing astigmatism, as the femtosecond laser can create precise incisions that help correct astigmatism while offering enhanced precision in other surgical steps. Laser-Assisted Surgical Steps: Post-Laser Surgical Steps : After the laser portion, the patient is moved to an operating microscope where the surgeon completes the remaining steps:

questions.question: A 70-year-old woman presents for cataract surgery in her right eye. She has moderate cataract density with some nuclear sclerosis and a clear cornea. She expresses a strong desire for a procedure that minimizes recovery time and provides optimal visual outcomes. Which of the following statements accurately reflects the advantage of Phacoemulsification Over Manual SICS? Phacoemulsification.

options.A: Manual SICS typically requires a smaller incision compared to Phacoemulsification.
options.B: Manual SICS allows for faster visual recovery compared to Phacoemulsification.
options.C: Manual SICS is less suitable for very hard cataracts compared to Phacoemulsification.
options.D: Manual SICS usually results in a higher level of postoperative astigmatism compared to

questions.explanation: compared to Phacoemulsification. Correct Answer : D) Manual SICS usually results in a higher level of postoperative astigmatism compared to Phacoemulsification. Explanation Manual SICS usually results in a higher level of postoperative astigmatism compared to Phacoemulsification as they use larger incisions. Aspect Manual SICS Phacoemulsification Procedure Type Extracapsular Cataract Extraction (ECCE) Extracapsular Cataract Extraction (ECCE) Incision Type Self-sealing, valvular, sclerocorneal tunnel incision Self-sealing, valvular, sclerocorneal tunnel incision or clear corneal incision . Anesthesia Local anesthesia (can be performed under) Local anesthesia (can also be performed under topical anesthesia) Nucleus Removal Method Manually extracted through the incision after being maneuvered out of the capsular bag Fragmented using an ultrasonic probe and then aspirated Suitability (Option C) Suitable for all cataract densities, including very hard cataracts Typically requires a smaller incision, less suitable for very hard cataracts Visual Recovery (Option B) Slower visual recovery, delayed return to optimal vision Faster visual rehabilitation due to smaller incision and reduced tissue manipulation Astigmatism (Option A) Higher levels of surgically induced astigmatism, larger incision Less postoperative astigmatism due to smaller incision size Complication Risks Lower risk of nuclear drop Higher risk of postoperative pain and inflammation, hyphema and conjunctival congestion Lower risk of postoperative pain, conjunctival congestion, hyphema and inflammation Overall Accessibility More accessible due to cost-effectiveness and versatility Preferred in settings with better resources and where faster recovery is prioritized Reference: Yanoff & Duker Ophthalmology, 6th edition, Pg 308 e1,2,3 Kanski’s Clinical Opthalmology, 10th edition, Pg 321 AK Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 7th edition, page 205, 208-212

questions.question: Which of the following steps is used to maintain the depth of the anterior chamber and protect the corneal endothelium during Conventional ECCE?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Viscoelastic injection Explanation : This step involves injecting a viscoelastic substance into the anterior chamber to maintain its depth and protect the corneal endothelium during the surgery. Extracapsular Cataract Extraction (ECCE): A type of cataract surgery where the lens is removed but the posterior capsule remains intact, allowing for various techniques to be applied based on patient age and lens stability. ECCE Techniques Conventional ECCE : Traditional method involving a large incision and removal of the lens while leaving the posterior capsule intact. Manual Small Incision Cataract Surgery (SICS) : Involves a self-sealing, sutureless incision; less technically demanding and more cost-effective. Phacoemulsification : Preferred method worldwide; uses ultrasonic vibrations to emulsify the lens through a small incision, followed by IOL implantation. Surgery Site of incision Size of incision Conventional ECCE At the limbus 8-10mm SICS Sclera 5-7mm Phacoemulsification Cornea 2.2-3.2mm Microincision (MICS) Cornea <1.8mm Surgical Steps of Conventional ECCE Eye Stabilization : Superior rectus suture for downward gaze(known as bridle suture) Conjunctival Flap Creation : A fornix-based flap will be used to expose the limbus. Limbal Incision : Partial-thickness groove across the limbus. Anterior Chamber Access : Entry with a razor blade knife or keratome. Viscoelastic Injection : Maintains chamber depth and protects the cornea. (Option B) Anterior Capsulotomy : Methods include can-opener, linear capsulotomy, envelope, or CCC. (Option A ruled out) Capsule Removal : Using forceps remove the cut capsule. Corneoscleral Section Completion : Extending the incision. (Option C ruled out) Hydrodissection : Separates the lens from the capsule. (Option D ruled out) Nucleus Removal : Methods include pressure/counter pressure or irrigating wire vectis. Cortex Aspiration : Using a two-way cannula. (I/A) IOL Implantation : Posterior chamber IOL into the capsular bag. Incision Closure : With sutures. Viscoelastic Removal : Followed by refilling the anterior chamber with irrigating fluid. Conjunctival Flap Repositioning : Secured in place. Subconjunctival Injections : Dexamethasone and gentamicin. Eye Patching : Final step. Advantages of ECCE over ICCE ECCE is suitable for all ages with intact zonules. ECCE allows for posterior chamber IOL implantation, unlike ICCE. Lower risk of vitreous-related complications with ECCE. Lower rates of endophthalmitis, cystoid macular edema, and retinal detachment with ECCE. ECCE reduces the risk of secondary rubeosis in diabetics. ECCE carries a lower risk of Postoperative Astigmatism. Better prognosis for later glaucoma surgery or corneal transplantation with ECCE.

questions.question: A 38-year-old patient with diabetes presents with rapidly worsening vision. Upon examination, the ophthalmologist notes the presence of bilateral, snowflake-like white opacities in the cortex of the lens. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer : C) Diabetic cataract Explanation : Diabetic cataract (aka Presenile cataract) is characterized by bilateral, snowflake-like white opacities in the lens cortex, typically seen in young adults with diabetes. Opacities may either resolve spontaneously or progress to maturity within days. Senile cataract (Option A) typically affects older individuals, although it can occur earlier in diabetics; however, it does not present with snowflake-like opacities. Christmas tree cataract (Option B) is associated with myotonic dystrophy, not diabetes. Posterior subcapsular cataract (Option D) can be seen in various conditions, including myotonic dystrophy, but does not present with the snowflake-like opacity as seen in true diabetic cataract. Reference: Yanoff & Duker Ophthalmology, 6th edition, Pg 310 Kanski’s Clinical Opthalmology, 10th edition, Pg 503

questions.question: A 35-year-old man presents with decreased vision in his right eye following a blunt trauma a few weeks ago. On examination, feathery opacities are noted. What is the most likely type of cataract this patient has developed?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Rosette cataract Explanation: Early Rosette Cataract is characterized by feathery opacities along suture lines, as seen in this patient. A traumatic cataract is an acquired cataract resulting from ocular trauma, such as penetrating or blunt injuries. It forms due to degeneration in previously normal lens fibers. Morphological Forms Subepithelial Opacities: Most common presentation. Rosette Cataracts: Early Rosette: Feathery opacities along posterior cortex suture lines; typical of concussion cataracts. (Option C) Late Rosette: Develops 1-2 years post-injury, with shorter, compact sutural extensions. Diffuse concussion cataract: Common presentation of total cataract following blunt trauma, which may accelerate senile cataract development. Subepithelial opacities (Option A) are common but do not typically present with feathery opacities along suture lines. Diffuse concussion cataract (Option B) involves widespread lens opacity, not localized feathery patterns.

questions.question: Match the type of cataract with the etiology Type of cataract Etiology a. Posterior subcapsular 1. Glassblowers b. Anterior subcapsular-granular 2. Miotics c. Posterior cortical 3. Steroids
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) a3,b2,c1 Explanation: Toxic cataract: Steroids - Prolonged use in high doses may cause posterior subcapsular cataracts. Children are more susceptible Other causes of posterior subcapsular cataract: Galactosemia, Myotonic dystrophy, BLUNT trauma, complicated cataract, chloroquine, busulfan, NF2, Glaucoma by TOPICAL steroids and cataract by SYSTEMIC STEROIDS (mnemonic: GTCS) Miotics - Especially long-acting cholinesterase inhibitors such as echothiophate, demecarium bromide, and diisopropyl fluorophosphate (DFP) may cause anterior subcapsular-granular cataracts Other causes of anterior subcapsular cataract - Amiodarone, chlorpromazine, busulfan, gold, and allopurinol AACG ( Mnemonic): Atopic dermatitis- shield cataract, Amiodarone, Chlorpromazine, Gold deposit, AACG(acute angle closure glaucoma) Radiation cataract: Infrared (heat) cataract - Infrared aka glassblower cataract Lens capsule exfoliation with discoid posterior opacities X-ray, gamma rays, neutron exposure: Inadequately protected technicians, patients treated for malignant tumors, and workers of atomic energy plants are at risk. Traumatic cataract: blunt trauma: Rosette cataract It is a cortical cataract that starts from the posterior cortex. Electric Shock cataract/ Lightening cataract: It leads to Stellate ASC

questions.question: A 30-year-old male with retinitis pigmentosa has developed a cataract as a complication. Which of the following is a feature of his cataract? Posterior subcapsular cortical cataract Irregular in outline Variable density Breadcrumb appearance Polychromatic luster Diffuse yellow haze in the adjoining cortex
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 1,2,3,4,5,6 Explanation: All of the listed features are that of complicated cataracts Complicated cataract: Definition Cataracts which develop as a complication of some other intraocular disease Causes (mnemonic: UMAR: -Uveitis -Myopia -Angle-closure glaucoma -Retinitis pigmentosa) Inflammations (Anterior uveitis is the most common cause of complicated cataracts) Degenerative conditions such as retinitis pigmentosa and myopic chorioretinal degeneration Long-standing retinal detachment Glaucoma (primary or secondary) Intraocular tumors in late stages (retinoblastoma or melanoma) Features Starts as a posterior subcapsular cortical cataract (PSC) Irregular outline Variable in density Slit-lamp: "Breadcrumb” appearance 'Polychromatic luster” , i.e. appearance of iridescent colored particles of reds, greens, and blue Diffuse yellow haze in the adjoining cortex

questions.question: Which of the following is not a feature of chalcosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Oil droplet cataract Explanation: Oil droplet cataract is seen in galactosemia, not chalcosis. Chalcosis: Definition Specific changes produced by the alloy of copper in the eye Mechanism Copper ions from the alloy are dissociated electrolytically and deposited under the membranous structures of the eye Clinical features Kayser-Fleischer ring (Option A) : Golden brown ring due to deposition of copper under the peripheral parts of Descemet's membrane of the cornea Sunflower cataract (Option B) : Deposition of copper under the posterior capsule of the lens Retina: Golden plaques (Option C) at the posterior pole that reflect the light with metallic luster

questions.question: A 6-month-old girl was diagnosed with galactosemia. An ocular examination has revealed a cataract which developed as a complication. Which of the following statements regarding her cataract is false?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Periphery of the lens Explanation: Galactosemia cataracts are central lens cataracts, not peripheral lens cataracts Galactosemia Inborn error of galactose metabolism Enzyme deficiency Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GPUT) Galactokinase (GK) Type of cataract Bilateral (Option A) “Oil droplet” (Option B) Central lens (Option C is the false statement) Features May be reversed (Option D) May be prevented if milk and milk products are eliminated at an early stage Reference: Yanoff & Duker Ophthalmology, 6th Edition, Page 316, 317, 370 Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 10th Edition, Page 337, 338

questions.question: A 45-year-old man is having difficulty in near vision. The ophthalmologist has prescribed him a convex lens and informed him that it is an age-related physiological condition. Which of the following is an age-related change that would have caused his condition?

options.A: Decrease in elasticity of lens capsule

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All of the above Explanation: The scenario is that of presbyopia Accommodation The mechanism by which the eyes focus diverging rays from a near object on the retina Mechanism When looking at a near object from a far object: Ciliary muscles contract → Zonules relax → Lens becomes more convex anteriorly Presbyopia Physiological insufficiency of accommodation, causing worsening near vision after the age of 40 Causes Decrease in elasticity of lens capsule (Option A) Sclerosis of lens substance (Option B) Reduced ciliary muscle power (Option C) Treatment Convex glasses for near-work A guide for powers required at various ages: 45 years: + l to +l.25D 50 years: +1.5 to +1.75D 55 years: +2 to +2.25D 60 years: +2.5 to +30D Reference: Kanski’s Clinical Opthalmology, 10th edition, Pg 393 AK Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 7th edition, pages 46-48

questions.question: An elderly male diabetic patient came with loss of vision in the left eye associated with pain in the left eye. On examination, the left eye appears red, and visual acuity- Perception of light+ and IOP is raised in the same eye. The patient gives history of blurring and diminution of vision for the past 1 year. The slit lamp examination is given below. Choose the correct diagnosis and appropriate pathophysiology for this patient.
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Phacolytic glaucoma - Secondary open-angle glaucoma Explanation: Given clinical scenario is suggestive of Glaucoma and the slit lamp image of a milky white cortex with a sunken nucleus corresponds to the Morgagnian type of hyper mature cataract - leading to secondary open-angle glaucoma called Phacolytic glaucoma. (Option C and D) Feature Phacomorphic Glaucoma Phacolytic Glaucoma Pathogenesis Intumescent cataract blocks the pupil. this pushes the iris forward, blocking the anterior chamber angle, leading to angle-closure glaucoma. Leakage of lens proteins from a hypermature cataract clogs the trabecular meshwork. Causes Intumescent cataract (mature cataract) Anterior subluxation of lens Spherophakia Hypermature (Morgagnian) cataract Obstruction of the trabecular meshwork by lens proteins. Clinical Features Symptoms are similar to acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Shallow anterior chamber. Ciliary congestion, dilated pupil, and swollen cataract is visible. Closed anterior chamber angle on gonioscopy. Features of acute congestive glaucoma due to high IOP. Deep anterior chamber. Open anterior chamber angle on gonioscopy. Management Medical

questions.question: An 80-year-old female patient came with complaints of gradual progressive diminution of vision for 2 years in both her eyes. She reports that over the last year, she noticed an improvement in her ability to read without glasses. The following finding is seen on slit lamp examination over the right eye and the left eye has similar opacity. Choose the most appropriate course of management for this patient.

options.A: Advise lifestyle modification and review after 3 months.
options.B: Recommend corticosteroids eye drops and reassess in 6 months.
options.D: Prescribe her rigid gas-permeable contact lenses.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Plan for Phacoemulsification. Explanation: Gradual progressive loss of vision and improvement of near vision (“Second sight”) with the slit lamp finding points towards diagnosis of Nuclear Cataract. Description and Pathophysiology Nuclear cataract/sclerosis- The etiology is nuclear sclerosis. Results from the gradual loss of lens elasticity and transparency due to dehydration, and increase in water-insoluble proteins. Clinical Features Glare Diplopia Colored Halos Blurred Vision/ Gradual Vision Loss Black spots in front of eyes. Deterioration of vision: In some patients with nuclear sclerosis, near vision improves due to progressive index myopia . Such patients may have improvement in their near-vision glasses. This improvement in near vision is referred to as 'second sight.’ Grading Nuclear Opacity (NO): Ranges from 1 (slight opacification) to 5 (severe

questions.question: A 70-year-old male patient comes to your clinic with complaints of glare and diminution of vision for 3 months. On examination, you notice the following appearance Choose the correct statement regarding the correct diagnosis.

options.A: The Iris shadow test becomes positive only when the whole cortex is involved.
options.B: Patients see better in dark surroundings.
options.C: Characterized by saucer-shaped opacities in the center of the posterior cortex.
options.D: Vision loss occurs at a late stage.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Vision loss occurs at a late stage. Explanation: An elderly patient with clinical features (glare/ diminution of vision/ blurred vision) suggestive of cataract and characteristic wedge-shaped opacities starting from periphery to center are noted, which points to a diagnosis of Cuneiform Senile Cortical Cataract. Type of Cataract Characteristics Visual Impact Cuneiform Senile Cortical Cataract Wedge-shaped opacities with clear areas in between. Extends from periphery to center . First appears in the lower nasal quadrant. Present in both anterior and posterior cortex. The radial spoke-like pattern of opacities is seen. Visual disturbances are noted at a comparatively late stage (since it starts at the periphery). (Option D) Vision improves in bright light with contracted pupils. (Option B) Cupuliform Senile Cortical Cataract Saucer-shaped opacities are typically in the central part of the posterior cortex ( posterior subcapsular cataract). (Option C) Extends from center to periphery. Causes an early loss of visual acuity.- Due to the involvement of the nodal point Glares seen in PSC Better vision in dim light with dilated pupils. Stages of Cortical cataract: Stage Description Characteristics 1. Stage of Lamellar Separation Earliest stage of senile cataract Formation of vacuoles and water clefts within the cortex Reversible change Can only be demonstrated by slit lamp examination 2. Stage of Incipient Cataract Detectable opacities with clear areas present between. Causes visual disturbances. Cuneiform type: Wedge-shaped opacities, extending from the equator appear as radial spoke-like opacities. Cupuliform type: Saucer-shaped opacity in the central posterior

questions.question: Which among the following is/are true statements regarding lens proteins? α / β / γ -Crystallins are water-soluble proteins Major intrinsic proteins contribute to lens transparency An increase in crystallins can lead to cataract β / γ -Crystallin family are the largest crystallins
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 1 & 2 Explanation: Lens proteins are broadly divided into soluble fractions and insoluble fractions. The water-soluble fraction consists of crystallins α / β / γ (Statement 1) , which make up about 90% of the lens's total protein content. The α crystallins are the largest crystallins (Statement 4) followed by β and γ respectively. The insoluble fraction of the lens consists of albuminoids - mainly major intrinsic proteins (MIP26/Aquaporin-0) and other cytoskeletal proteins. (Statement 2) A decrease in crystallins and an increase in albuminoids can lead to cataract formation. (Statement 3) Other proteins: HMV-3,4; accumulation of HMV-4 can give rise to nuclear cataract. Reference: Yanoff and Duker Ophthalmology, 6th Edition, Page 307

questions.question: What is the consequence of age-related decline in the Na+-K+ ATPase pump in the lens?

options.A: Increased intralenticular K+ levels and decreased Na+ levels.
options.B: Increased intralenticular Na+ levels and decreased K+ levels.

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Increased intralenticular Na+ levels and decreased K+ levels. Explanation: Pump leak theory: The mechanism that prevents water from getting into the lens is known as the pump-leak theory. Over the Anterior surface of the lens, Na+-K+ ATPase pumps out Na+ and pumps in K+ into the lens. The leak happens in the posterior surface i.e. ions (K+) and molecules passively diffuse across a concentration gradient . Enhanced ion exchange efficiency (Option C): Dysfunction of the sodium-potassium ATPase pump leads to decreased ion exchange efficiency, not enhanced efficiency. Reference: Yanoff & Duker Ophthalmology 5th edition - page 326-e7, 331.
